meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny!

Get ready for a juicy review of Cupid Parasite: Sweet and Spicy Darling, because I'm about to dish out the tea on this adorable otome visual novel. And trust me, folks, you won't want to miss it.

First off, let's get one thing straight - if you haven't played the original Cupid Parasite, don't even think about diving into this fandisc without a solid grasp of the first game's storyline. You'll be lost in a sea of confused emotions, and honestly, who wants that?

Now, onto the good stuff! Sweet and Spicy Darling is a delightful sequel that wraps up the original's story with flair and humor. Returning fans will be thrilled to see their favorite characters grow and flourish in this full-length sequel, while newbies can jump right in (after playing the first game, of course). The storytelling is top-notch, with each route taking a few hours to complete - perfect for a cozy night in or a quick gaming fix.

But what really sets Sweet and Spicy Darling apart is its gorgeous color palette. Imagine walking into a whimsical wonderland filled with vibrant hues and adorable characters. That's exactly what you'll get in this game! The menus are easy to navigate, and the wildly different plot routes will keep you hooked from start to finish.

Now, let's talk about those pesky critics (wink). NintendoWorldReport gave it a solid 80, praising its ability to subsume the original. God is a Geek gave it a more modest 75, but noted that it's still a wonderful take on the otome genre - just not for newbies. Cubed3 and Digitally Downloaded both awarded it an impressive 90, with Cubed3 raving about the game's perfect balance of backstory telling and route choices. Tech-Gaming chimed in with an 81, highlighting the compelling codas and romance.

On the flip side, Gamer Escape gave it a 60, citing a lack of world-building and character development - not exactly what you want from a sequel. And GLHF on Sports Illustrated? A mixed bag, folks! They enjoyed the slice-of-life storytelling and character arcs but felt the game was "all over the place."

So, is Cupid Parasite: Sweet and Spicy Darling worth your time? If you're a fan of otome games or just looking for a sweet (pun intended) romance story, then absolutely. Just don't forget to play the original first - trust me, it's worth it.

That's all for now, folks! I hope you enjoyed this review as much as I did. Happy gaming, and remember: Hippo Penny is always here to dish out the tea on your favorite games.
